channel.title: Grover Lab
channel.description:
Grover Lab
Department of Bioengineering
University of California, Riverside
Riverside, CA 92521

item.title: Doug's system of "building blocks" for creating instruments published in PLOS ONE
item.description: Doug Hill’s paper “MECs: ‘Building Blocks’ for Creating Biological and Chemical Instruments” was published in PLOS ONE. Thanks to our coauthors Lindsey Anderson, Casey Hill, Afshin Mostaghim, and Victor G. J. Rodgers for their help!

item.title: Dr. Grover talks about density at TEDxUCR
item.description: Dr. Grover shared his favorite physical property—density—with the audience at the 2016 TEDxUCR.

item.title: Congressman Mark Takano visits the lab
item.description: Thanks to Congressman Mark Takano for visiting the lab!

item.title: Nazila and Heran's work on orientation-based control of microfluidics published in PLOS ONE
item.description: Nazila Norouzi and Heran Bhakta’s paper “Orientation-Based Control of Microfluidics” was published in PLOS ONE.

item.title: Shirin featured in UCR Magazine
item.description: Graduate student Shirin Mesbah Oskui was featured in the Winter 2016 issue of UCR Magazine.

item.title: Shirin's work on the toxicity of 3D-printed parts published in Environmental Science and Technology Letters
item.description: Shirin Mesbah Oskui’s paper “Assessing and Reducing the Toxicity of 3D-Printed Parts” was published in Environmental Science and Technology Letters.

item.title: Anechoic: a smartphone app for sonic experimentation
item.description: Check out Anechoic, an iPhone app we’re developing for giving K-12 students firsthand experience with the principles behind techniques like ultrasound and sonar.

item.title: Why is undergraduate research important?
item.description: Why is undergraduate research important? Dr. Grover shares his thoughts in a UCR Career Center blog post.

item.title: Undergrads' Diaper Detective wins third place in NIH/NIBIB DEBUT Challenge
item.description:
The Diaper Detective (the Senior Design Project of Bioengineering undergrads Stephanie Tehseldar, Veronica Boulos, Sara Said, Claire Tran and Melissa Cruz) won third place and a $10,000 prize in the NIH/NIBIB Design by Undergraduate Biomedical Teams (DEBUT) Challenge!

The Diaper Detective was also featured on:

  • CBS 2 Los Angeles: “UCR students invent diaper pad that detects infection, other medical conditions”

  • c-net: “Diaper Detective smart pad senses dehydration, infection”

  • Engadget: “Super cheap diaper insert alerts parents to dehydration and more”

  • Phys.org: “Diaper pad to detect dehydration and bacterial infections in infants”

  • Riverside Press-Enterprise: “UC Riverside students turn diaper into medical tool”

  • UCR homepage: “Team of engineering students develop inexpensive, versatile pad to detect medical problems in infants”
